title: Penny Post Card and Model "T" Ford

content: In those days outside manufactured parts came in wooden crates. Old man Ford was very particular about how the parts were packed. He even gave dimensions and specifications for the crates. After the crates were empty a worker would break them down and they were used as floor boards and other wooden parts in the Model Ts. What wood he couldnt use, he had converted to charcoal and sold. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
reply: In those days outside manufactured parts came in wooden crates. Old man Ford was very particular about how the parts were packed. He even gave dimensions and specifications for the crates. After the crates were empty a worker would break them down and they were used as floor boards and other wooden parts in the Model Ts. What wood he couldnt use, he had converted to charcoal and sold. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
title: Penny Post Card and Model "T" Ford

content: I hate to admit it but I remember when a postcard was 1¢, second class mail was 2¢ and first class mail was 3¢. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

content: quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: In those days outside manufactured parts came in wooden crates. Old man Ford was very particular about how the parts were packed. He even gave dimensions and specifications for the crates. After the crates were empty a worker would break them down and they were used as floor boards and other wooden parts in the Model Ts. What wood he couldnt use, he had converted to charcoal and sold. One day I was reading the Kingsford charcoal bag while I was waiting for it to turn gray and there is a story about how Kingsford was Henry Ford's brother-in-law who set up a charcoal making factory for use in makeing the metal for the cars.
quote: Originally posted by Vicdude: In those days outside manufactured parts came in wooden crates. Old man Ford was very particular about how the parts were packed. He even gave dimensions and specifications for the crates. After the crates were empty a worker would break them down and they were used as floor boards and other wooden parts in the Model Ts. What wood he couldnt use, he had converted to charcoal and sold.
